It would make sense to perform destructive testing for all of the earlier models. For those that don't fly, they could do destructive static tests on the ground. Pressure tests, thermal tests, and impact tests for example. That data would be relatively cheap and easy to acquire and potentially useful for exploring limits or confirming them. Even if the design changes quite a bit, they would still be a data point for comparison.

Block is a long use term for military/contractor change methodology.  Make a list of updates.  Prioritize a subset of the changes/improvements into a group.  That group is called a block.  When you finish one block of changes, prepare a new prioritized subset - that is the next block.

It seemed pretty clear to me, early on, that the word "block" simply STARTED as a CASUAL, just-kind-of-thrown-out-there word between engineers and manufacturers... THAT'S ALL it was!

So... some everyday Joe... looking at a list of engines that the team needed for a certain "block" of time referred to them as the first block of engines. Later, when they were running out of engines and knew what they needed to improve on the next BLOCK of engines, made the improvements and referred to them as... this second BLOCK of engines are way cooler than the first block of engines... and so on and so forth.
They may have well have used the word "lot" or "bunch" or "shipment".
Somewhere down the line somebody came along who was not in the loop thought that it was some serious engineering term. And that's how it came to us. Who knows... maybe Elon himself was never in the loop. shrugs
Nothing magical... nothing technical... nothing particularly important.

It was the core support structure separating the cockpit and the body of the plane.  Look it up, it is immense and took weeks of machining.

it's not necessarily Block 1,2,3,4,5. look at the F-16. Block 1,5, 10, 15, 20 for the A models, Block 25 for the first C models, and
when they introduced the common engine bay it went to 30/32, 40/42, 50/52 etc for the P&W/GE engines, respectively. it's just a designation, they can apply it at their own discretion and doesn't need to make logical sense for outsiders other than to indicate a difference. See SLS Block 1, 1A, 1B for different mission profiles.

I’m not sure it would still work in current versions if KSP, I don’t think engine bells still function as magic heat shields. Maybe I’m misremembering and it used a fair amount of fuel decelerating prior to the major heating.

In any case, I thought flying it back and landing it propulsively was making a rod for their own back.

Very informative.  Noted an error with the statement that titanium grid fins were the largest forged titanium in the world.  I saw forged Ti airplane landing gears at VSMPO Titanium in Russia. Regardless, the Falcon V1.2 is a spectacular success and the booster landings are a marvelous achievement and just a thing of beauty.

It makes perfect sense to use the earlier block models for extreme testing. As you said, those are data points that can provide a list of options in the event something really weird happens on a critical launch. They could even do things like having a grid fin break off during the re-entry burn to see if it is controllable with only three fins. Maybe tumble the booster and see if the attitude jets can recover from a tumble or a spin. Fail more than one engine in an asymmetrical pattern to see how the system adapts.

I'm afraid you got some of those thrust figures wrong:

- That v1.0 figure was for v1.0 Block 2, which never flew. Block 1 had lower thrust, though the actual figure is hard to find (some sources claim 450kN per engine, others 480).
- 7607kN, the current figure on SpaceX's website, is for Block 5. Pre-Block 5 v1.2 was 6806kN.

I want to see rapid reuse of booster & launch price fall to less than 20 millions USD.
When that happen, I will be more confident that humankind's future in space is assured.
BFR will just settle the debate & crystallize that conviction.
From that point on, I would expect massive improvements in space based science & technology within the next 10 years.

As always, you can't innovate in space technology, if you don't live in space.
Live experience is the best teacher you can have & will make the R&D process accelerate dramatically.

This might just be me, but I think Elon has some plans for future rockets that we haven't heard of yet. For example, once the BFR is up and running, I wouldn't be surprised if he made a BFR heavy (3 BFRs strapped together like the Falcon Heavy is). This would allow him to get even heavier payloads into orbit, but I also think he might need to make an even bigger and newer BFS. This is because if he wants to bring a million people to Mars, he will need to transport more than the hundred or so the BFS is supposed to take in one go. He would need to be looking at numbers approaching 1000 if he wants to probably make that dream a reality. Basically, I think the BFR and BFS will just end up being placeholders for something bigger.

Just seeing comments about #metricfirst. I assume this means you give details is SI units first then in good old imperial measurements second. I grew up in the UK as we metricized and learnt physics using the Systeme Intenational (SI units). Believe me every thing makes sense in SI. First off, mass (kilograms) is a totally different animal to weight (pounds force), but non physicists think mass and weight are the same thing. They are related in a constant gravitational field (just as energy and mass are related everywhere). S.I is the third best thing the French have ever exported. After Chateauneuf du Pape and Roquefort cheese.

Some Comments:

1) I don't think the grid fins are the largest forgings ever, perhaps currently, but SR-71 had monster Titanium forgings. Hell the F-14 Tomcat wing box was massive. A lot of modern aircraft have moved to carbon fiber and I know what Musk said at the SES reuse press event but still skeptical.

2) The Merlin turbine wheel micro-crack issue was detected on static fire at McGregor. No need to actually fly the engine to discover this condition. Other ones do get cracks RS-25 and RS-68 both had/have turbine cracking issues and were known even before they ever flew.

3) Yes, block 1-5 is in the FT family.

4) Also, they don't have space to store all the cores (aside from the recovery cost and the refurb costs of block 1-4)

Edit: As others have noted, Musk said grid fins are castings not forgings

As someone who worked for a company that sold a similar number (low hundreds) of individual, cutting-edge, custom, multi-million dollar devices, it's likely that the naming scheme is not consistent even in-house. Each machine of ours sold was a known quantity, but typically could have any of half-a-dozen or more custom features, even as some cost-plus features became standard, and old standard features became obsolete. Like SpaceX, there was a certain amount of jockeying for delivery positions, and newer serial numbers not rarely had older features and vice-versa. There were 'blocks' of various sorts, some involving visible changes, that made them distinguishable to experts, but also many internal options that were not visible or readily discerned.
Since these devices were not expended, it also happened that they were occasionally upgraded after delivery. Sometimes by the customer (breaking their contract).
As the numbers we delivered grew, with a few exceptions the configurables became increasingly standardized and externally visible. The models grew to correspond increasingly to the serial numbers; by the time we reached ~100 devices, the serial numbers were split into basic chassis groupings, and each chassis class took similar or identical modules, even across chassis.

More reasons for throwing away stages: (1) They have had serious trouble finding enough space to store used stages, and those problems increased with increasing flight rate (and additional harbor storage will only partially alleviate that). (2) Also at least one recovery was hindered by bad weather in the recovery area at sea (and they prioritized timely launch over recovery then).
However, for block 5 there will of course be some adjustments in strategies, priorities and numbers for this.
